page.title: 11W.W.11 IN CHIPPING WARDEN
page.content: Chipping Warden was a very small village until the second world war when lots of Nisson huts were built for people to live in. Chipping Warden was chosen as an airfield and the nisson hut were for the airmen to live in. There was also a Naafi and a hospital. The NAAFI is now a smallholding. The stage of the hall is still there, in a barn. The hospital is now the school. The hangers on the aerodrome are now part of the industrial estate. The runways are still there. The nisson huts were in Culworth Road, one is now the football club's hut, Appletree Road and on the main road. At the end of the war, squatters moved into the houses on the main road until Arbury Banks was built and families moved into those houses from the huts.
